text: So again, how would you say to think?
Penser.
And how would you say you formal think?
Vous pensez.
How would you say you think so?
Literally, you think that yes.
Vous pensez que oui.
How about we think so?
Nous pensons que oui.
How about I think so?
Je pense que oui.
He thinks so.
Il pense que oui.
She thinks so.
Elle pense que oui.
You, informal, think so.
Tu penses que oui.
Finally, they think so.
Il pense que oui.
They, an entirely female group, think so.
Elle pense que oui.
They think that I want to leave.
Ils pensent que je veux partir.
But I think that they want to leave.
Mais je pense qu'ils veulent partir.
You may notice that the word for that which is que, and which is followed by they, which is
they contract.
They contract and become qu'ils.
So again, listening carefully, how would you say, I think that they want to leave.
You don't need to worry too much about always making sure to abbreviate that when you're speaking.
But as time passes, it will become quite natural to say qu'ils.
And you'll realise that it's simply easier and easier to say it when you're speaking French.
How would you say, he thinks that they want to leave.
They think that they want to go out this evening.
They think that they want to go out this evening.

They think that they want to go out this evening.

They think that they want to go out this evening.
They think that they want to go out this evening.

They think that they want to go out this evening.
